medium_description_en: Rates level of anxiety based on clinical questions.

seo.meta_description_en: The Hamilton Anxiety Scale rates level of anxiety based on clinical questions.
seo.keywords_en: Anxiety level, hamilton anxiety, hamilton anxiety score, hamilton gad score, anxiety rating, hamilton rating, hamilton calc, hamilton anxiety calc, HAM-A calc, hamilton anxiety calc, hamilton anxiety level, anxiety level assessment, ham anx, ham anxiety, hamilton anx, hamilton anx level, hamilton anx dx, hamilton anx diagnosis, hamilton anxiety dx, hamilton anxiety diagnosis

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Evaluating new patients to assess their level of anxiety and functioning.
  • Trending a patient’s anxiety level over time.
how_to_use.why_use_en: The Hamilton Anxiety Scale can help objectify and rate the severity of a patient's anxiety.

next_steps.advice_en: Patients with anxiety can often benefit from cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); most can be managed as outpatients.

about.formula_en:
Addition of the selected points.

Point Values:

  • 0=Not Present
  • +1=Mild
  • +2=Moderate
  • +3=Severe
  • +4=Very Severe
about.more_info_en:
Score interpretation:

  • Scores ≤17 indicate mild anxiety severity.
  • Scores of 18-24 indicate mild to moderate anxiety severity
  • Scores of 25-30 indicate moderate to severe anxiety severity
  • Scores >30 indicate severe anxiety

Validation.text: Maier W, Buller R, Philipp M, Heuser I. The Hamilton Anxiety Scale: reliability, validity and sensitivity to change in anxiety and depressive disorders. J Affect Disord 1988;14(1):61–8.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Hamilton M. The assessment of anxiety states by rating. Br J Med Psychol 1959; 32:50–55.

Other References.text: Per Bech. Measuring States of Anxiety with Clinician-Rated and Patient-Rated Scales, Different Views of Anxiety Disorders. 2011, DOI: 10.5772/21246.

creator_info.about_en: Max Hamilton, MD, FRCP, (d. 1988) was a senior lecturer in psychiatry at the University of Leeds in England. He was also president of the British Psychological Society and received the Paul Hoch Prize for Distinguished Psychiatric Research from the American Psychopathological Association in 1980. Dr. Hamilton’s research focused primarily on psychometrics and clinical statistics.

input_schema.label_en: 1. Anxious mood: Worries, anticipation of the worst, fearful anticipation, irritability.
input_schema.name: mood

input_schema.label_en: 2. Tension: Feelings of tension, fatigability, startle response, moved to tears easily, trembling, feelings of restlessness, inability to relax.
input_schema.name: tension

input_schema.label_en: 3. Fears: Of dark, of strangers, of being left alone, of animals, of traffic, of crowds.
input_schema.name: fears

input_schema.label_en: 4. Insomnia: Difficulty in falling asleep, broken sleep, unsatisfying sleep and fatigue on waking, dreams, nightmares, night terrors.
input_schema.name: insomnia

input_schema.label_en: 5. Intellectual: Difficulty in concentration, poor memory.
input_schema.name: intellectual

input_schema.label_en: 6. Depressed mood: Loss of interest, lack of pleasure in hobbies, depression, early waking, diurnal swing.
input_schema.name: depressed_mood

input_schema.label_en: 7. Somatic (muscular): Pains and aches, twitching, stiffness, myoclonic jerks, grinding of teeth, unsteady voice, increased muscular tone.
input_schema.name: somatic_muscular

input_schema.label_en: 8. Somatic (sensory): Tinnitus, blurring of vision, hot and cold flushes, feelings of weakness, pricking sensation.
input_schema.name: somatic_sensory

input_schema.label_en: 9. Cardiovascular symptoms: Tachycardia, palpitations, pain in chest, throbbing of vessels, fainting feelings, missing beat.
input_schema.name: cardiovascular

input_schema.label_en: 10 . Respiratory symptoms: Pressure or constriction in chest, choking feelings, sighing, dyspnea.
input_schema.name: respiratory

input_schema.label_en: 11. Gastrointestinal symptoms: Difficulty in swallowing, wind abdominal pain, burning sensations, abdominal fullness, nausea, vomiting, borborygmi, looseness of bowels, loss of weight, constipation.
input_schema.name: gastrointestinal

input_schema.label_en: 12. Genitourinary symptoms: Frequency of micturition, urgency of micturition, amenorrhea, menorrhagia, development of frigidity, premature ejaculation,loss of libido, impotence.
input_schema.name: genitourinary

input_schema.label_en: 13. Autonomic symptoms: Dry mouth, flushing, pallor, tendency to sweat, giddiness, tension headache, raising of hair.
input_schema.name: autonomic

input_schema.label_en: 14. Behavior at interview: Fidgeting, restlessness or pacing, tremor of hands, furrowed brow, strained face, sighing or rapid respiration, facial pallor, swallowing, etc.
input_schema.name: behavior
